The three films cited in the Supreme Court's decision yesterday on the Reagan Administration's right to label works as ''political propaganda'' were ''If You Love This Planet,'' ''Acid From Heaven'' and ''Acid Rain: Requiem or Recovery?'' All were produced by the National Film Board of Canada, and all deal with nuclear or environmental issues.

''If You Love This Planet,'' which won an Academy Award for short subjects in 1983, is a 25-minute film that centers on a lecture to American students by Dr. Helen Caldicott, an opponent of nuclear arms. The film also uses old newsreel film showing the effect of the atomic bomb on Hiroshima. When the film was released in 1982, National Film Board publicity said it made an argument for why ''disarmament can't be postoned.''

''Acid From Heaven,'' a 30-minute film, released in 1981, was a docudrama, with re-enacted scenes. The film board described it as ''a case study of someone whose income has been cut off because of acid rain,'' which is produced by sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide emitted in the combustion of fossil fuels.

''Acid Rain: Requiem or Recovery,'' a 26-minute film, also released in 1981, was perhaps the most ambitious of the three. It used standard documentary techniques and visited sites of apparent damage from acid rain, such as rivers in Nova Scotia or lakes in the Adirondacks.

The film also presented what it described as corrosion caused by acid rain on grave markers in Arlington National Cemetery and on the sheathing of the State of Liberty. The problem of acid rain, a narrator said at the conclusion of the film, can be solved ''only with public pressure on our board rooms and legislatures.''
